1. A 72-year-old female presents with sudden, painless vision loss in her right eye upon waking. She reports a new, persistent headache localized to her temples over the past two weeks and scalp tenderness when combing her hair. On examination, her right pupil is sluggishly reactive, and there is a relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundoscopy reveals a pale, swollen optic disc with peripapillary hemorrhages. She also complains of jaw claudication and general fatigue. Blood work shows an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). Temporal artery biopsy confirms granulomatous inflammation consistent with giant cell arteritis. Prompt initiation of high-dose corticosteroids is planned to prevent further vision loss.
What brings you in today?
output:

ANSWER: Well, I’m a 72-year-old woman, and I woke up today and couldn’t see out of my right eye at all. I’ve had this bad headache on my temples for a couple of weeks, and it’s been really sore when I try to comb my hair. I feel kind of tired and maybe a little strange overall.
